'''Scott Vestal''' is an American banjoist, songwriter and [[luthier]], known for his innovative approach to playing and designing the banjo.

== Biography ==
===Early years===
The older of two children, Scott Vestal was raised in Duncan, Oklahoma in a musical family. His Grandfather Famon Self was a country fiddler who taught Vestal his first guitar chords. Scott and his brother Curtis played and sang with their grandfather at bluegrass festivals and other events.<ref name=SV-newsletter-2017>{{cite web |url=https://banjonews.com/2017-09/callous_thumb.html|title=Callous Thumb|work=Banjo Newsletter|access-date=September 8, 2017|author=Donald Nitchie|date=September 1, 2017}}</ref>

===Music career===
Vestal acquired a 5-string banjo at age 13 and by age 15 was playing with T. J. Rogers’ family band. At age 18, Vestal performed and recorded with [[Larry Sparks]] for a year. At age 19, Vestal moved to Texas and with his brother Curtis and Russell Moore formed the band Southern Connection, which toured the Midwest and East Coast for 3 years.<ref name=SV-jazztimes-2000>{{cite web |url=https://jazztimes.com/departments/hearsay/scott-vestal/|title=Scott Vestal|work=JazzTimes|access-date=September 8, 2017|author=Sean Daly|date=July 1, 2000}}</ref>

In 1985, Vestal, Russell Moore, and Scott Vestal joined [[Doyle Lawson]] and Quicksilver, replacing [[Terry Baucom]].<ref name=SV-newsletter-2010>{{cite web |url=https://banjonews.com/2010-06/scott_vestal.html|title=Scott Vestal|work=Banjo Newsletter|access-date=September 7, 2017|author=Scott Anderson|date=June 1, 2010}}</ref> Vestal stayed with Quicksilver for four years and five albums.<ref name=SV-allcountry-1997>{{cite book 
|last=Erlewine|first=Michael|date=1997|title=All Music Guide to Country: The Experts' Guide to the Best Recordings in Country Music|publisher=Hal Leonard Corporation |isbn=9780879304751|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7Mo7xm-X1r4C|access-date=September 8, 2017}}</ref><ref name=SV-nodep-1999>{{cite news|last1=Weisberger|first1=Jon|title=Doyle Lawson & Quicksilver - The Original Band|url=http://nodepression.com/album-review/doyle-lawson-quicksilver-original-band|access-date=September 8, 2017|work=No Depression|date=April 30, 1999}}</ref>

Vestal then formed his group Livewire with mandolinist [[Wayne Benson]], guitarist and vocalist Robert Hale, and bassist Ernie Sykes.<ref name=SV-master-2015>{{cite book |last=Bay|first=William|date=Dec 10, 2015|title=Master Anthology of Mandolin Solos, Vol. 1|publisher=MEL BAY PUBN Incorporated |isbn=9780786693733|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J_ftjgEACAAJ|access-date=September 8, 2017}}</ref>  Vestal toured Japan with an acoustic jazz ensemble, and starred in Phyllis McBride's original musical production ''Cowboy Cafe''.<ref name=SV-newsletter-2010 /><ref name=SV-hvba-2009>{{cite web |url=http://www.hvbluegrass.org/articles/news/273-ernie-sykes-to-present-two-workshops.html|title=Ernie Sykes to Present Two Workshops
|work=Hudson Valley Bluegrass Association|access-date=September 8, 2017|date= November 10, 2009}}</ref>

In 1994, Vestal moved to Nashville and formed a band with [[Harley Allen]] and [[David Parmley]]. When Allen decided to focus on songwriting, the band became David Parmley, Scott Vestal, and Continental Divide. Over the next 5 years, the band recorded three albums and toured the US and Canada.<ref name=SV-tribune-1995>{{cite news|last1=Duckman|first1=David|title=David Parmley, Scott Vestal & Continental Divide...|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/1995/10/19/david-parmley-scott-vestal-continental-dividedavid/|access-date=September 8, 2017|work=Chicago Tribune|date=October 19, 1995}}</ref> Vestal left Continental Divide in 1998.<ref name=SV-billboard-2000>{{cite magazine|last1=Evans Price|first1=Deborah|title=Parmley Takes Act Back to Bluegrass|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4Q0EAAAAMBAJ&q=scott+vestal+continental+divide&pg=PA30|access-date=September 8, 2017|magazine=Billboard|date=February 12, 2000}}</ref>

Vestal produced, engineered, and played on an annual series of instrumental albums for [[Pinecastle Records]]. The initial project started as a solo album for [[Mountain Heart]] guitarist Clay Jones. When Jones went another direction, Vestal salvaged the project as an instrumental album.<ref name=SV-bgtoday-2007>{{cite news|last1=Lawless|first1=John
|title=More Ultimate Pickin from Pinecastle|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/more-ultimate-pickin-from-pinecastle/|access-date=September 8, 2017|work=Bluegrass Today|date=February 13, 2007}}</ref><ref name=SV-billboard-1996>{{cite magazine|last1=Evans Price|first1=Deborah|title=McCoury Leads IBMA Awards|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0QkEAAAAMBAJ&q=bluegrass+%2795+pinecastle&pg=PA34|access-date=September 8, 2017|magazine=Billboard|date=October 5, 1996}}</ref>

The “Bluegrass Annual” series), which won the IBMA award for Recorded Event of the Year in 1996. This series of recordings continued from 1995 through 2001.<ref name=SV-newsletter-2010 />

Scott played on [[Johnny Staats]]’ mandolin project with [[John Cowan]]. From 1998 until 2003, Vestal and Cowan were in the John Cowan Band, and recorded two albums together. Vestal had the opportunity to incorporating a solid body electric MIDI banjo into their recordings and performances.<ref name=SV-cmt-2003>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1473110/the-long-journey-back-john-cowan-returns-to-his-grass-roots/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150104175126/http://www.cmt.com/news/1473110/the-long-journey-back-john-cowan-returns-to-his-grass-roots/|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 4, 2015|title=The Long Journey Back: John Cowan Returns to His 'Grass' Roots|work=CMT|access-date=September 8, 2017|author=Michelle Nikolai|date=June 23, 2003}}</ref>

In 2006, Vestal worked with [[David Lee Roth]] to promote the [[CMH Records]] Van Halen bluegrass tribute ''[[Strummin' with the Devil: The Southern Side of Van Halen]]'', appearing on late night and daytime talk shows and at a concert at the [[Nokia Theater (New York)|Nokia Theater]] in New York City.<ref name=SV-roth-2006>{{cite web |url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/david-lee-roth-tv-update/|title=David Lee Roth – TV update|work=Bluegrass Today|access-date=September 8, 2017|author=John Lawless|date=June 6, 2006}}</ref>

Starting in 2006, Vestal recorded and toured with the [[Sam Bush]] Band along with Stephen Mougin (guitar), Todd Parks (bass), and Chris Brown (drums).<ref name=SV-rutland-2016>{{cite news|last1=Edelstein|first1=Art|title='Father of newgrass': Sam Bush|url=http://www.rutlandherald.com/articles/father-of-newgrass-sam-bush/|access-date=September 8, 2017|work=Rutland Herald|date=March 31, 2016}}</ref><ref name=SV-amplifier-2012>{{cite web |url=http://www.bgamplifier.com/artists/musicians/john-cowan/article_448db57c-1c3f-11e5-a799-93413da0b106.html|title=John Cowan|work=The Amplifier|access-date=September 8, 2017|date=July 3, 2012}}</ref>

===Recording and session work===
As well as being a session player in Nashville, Vestal built Digital Underground, a recording studio where he engineers, produces, and performs on various projects.<ref name=SV-nodep-2010>{{cite news|last1=Jim|first1=Moulton|title="Crying Heart Blues" - Audey Blaylock and Redline - A Review
|url=http://nodepression.com/article/crying-heart-blues-audey-blaylock-and-redline-review|access-date=September 8, 2017|work=No Depression|date=June 4, 2010}}</ref>

Vestal has worked with [[Bill Monroe]], [[Tim O'Brien (musician)|Tim O'Brien]], [[Jim Lauderdale]], [[Shawn Camp (musician)|Shawn Camp]], [[Ricky Skaggs]], [[Jerry Douglas]], [[Tony Rice]], [[Vassar Clements]], [[Chris Thile]], [[Hank Williams III]], [[Kenny Chesney]], [[Del McCoury]], [[Dierks Bentley]], [[Billy Ray Cyrus]], [[Alan Jackson]], [[Dolly Parton]],<ref name=SV-dolly-2014>{{cite news|last1=Lawless|first1=John|title=Dolly Parton talks Blue Smoke|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/dolly-parton-talks-blue-smoke/|access-date=September 1, 2017|work=Bluegrass Today|date=May 15, 2014}}</ref> [[Dwight Yoakam]],<ref name=SV-kiim-2016>{{cite news|last1=staff|title=Dwight Yoakam to Release New Bluegrass Album, "Swimmin' Pools, Movie Stars," on Sept. 23|url=http://www.kiimfm.com/2016/08/02/dwight-yoakam-to-release-new-bluegrass-album-swimmin-pools-movie-stars-on-sept-23/|access-date=September 8, 2017|work=KIIM|date=August 2, 2016}}</ref> and others.

Vestal and his wife, jazz singer Alice Newman Vestal, recorded the album ''Goin’ To The Dance''. Steve Thomas (fiddle), Chris Brown (drums), Jeff Autry (guitar), Byron House (bass), and Randy Kohrs (resophonic guitar) assisted.<ref name=SV-newsletter-2010 /><ref name=SV-popmaters-2006>{{cite web |url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/asv-goin-to-the-dance/|title=ASV: Goin' To The Dance|work=PopMatters|access-date=September 8, 2017|author=Jason MacNeil|date=October 3, 2006}}</ref>

===Solo career===
Vestal wrote nine of thirteen songs on his first solo album ''In Pursuit Of Happiness'' and nine of twelve songs on his album ''Millennia''.

On Vestal's 1992 album ''In Pursuit Of Happiness'', the personnel are Curtis Vestal (bass), Jeff Autry (guitar), Wayne Benson (mandolin), and Greg Luck (fiddle).<ref name=SV-tribune2-1995>{{cite web |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1995-11-16/features/9511160150_1_signatures-pickers-impresses|title=Scott Vestal In Pursuit Of Happiness|work=Chicago Tribune|access-date=September 8, 2017|author=David Duckman|date=November 16, 1995}}{{dead link|date=September 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>

On ''Millennia'', released in 2000, Vestal is joined by John Cowan on vocals, Reese Winans on keyboards, Pasi Leppikangas on drums, Jeff Autry and Jim Hurst on guitars, and Stuart Duncan, Kati Penn, and Rickie Simpkins on fiddle.<ref name=SV-std-2000>{{cite web |url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=2522|title=Scott Vestal: Millennia|work=Country Standard Time|access-date=September 8, 2017|author=Jonathan Colcord}}</ref>

===Stealth Banjos===
Vestal's banjo company Stealth Banjos sells instruments he has designed and developed. It features an innovative hidden 5th string and a streamlined neck and headstock.<ref name=SV-acoustic-1998>{{cite web |url=http://www.stealthbanjo.com/Review.am.html|title=Stealth Banjo Review|work=Acoustic Magazine|access-date=September 7, 2017|author=Casey Henry|date=February 1, 1998}}</ref>

===Awards===
Scott was awarded Banjo Player of the Year in 1996 by the International Bluegrass Music Association (co-winner with [[Sammy Shelor]]), and 1998 Banjo Player of the Year by the Bluegrass Now Magazine Fan's Choice Awards.

In 2017, Vestal was awarded the [[Steve Martin]] Prize for Excellence in Banjo and Bluegrass.<ref name=SV-nyt-2017>{{cite news|last1=Libbey|first1=Peter|title=Scott Vestal Wins Steve Martin Banjo Prize|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/30/arts/music/scott-vestal-wins-steve-martin-banjo-prize.html|access-date=September 7, 2017|work=The New York Times|date=July 30, 2017}}</ref>
